solve but before we get there I think
it's useful to understand what the

looks like this is something which after
I joined select I realize is fairly
complicated in itself so the process
starts about a year before the products
are actually placed in the store and
that is what we call the plan
optimization phase you can see on the

make decisions if it's fall 2017 i
retailers are making decisions about
fall 2018 in terms of how they should
allocate the budget to different

products under consideration so there's
some amount of demand that needs to be

next phase is the buy optimization phase
and that will be the focus of this short
talk this is the phase which occurs
about one quarter in advance of actually
placing the product in the store so if
it's fall 2017 I'm looking at products
for vintage
2018 and figuring out okay these are the
products I see on the market and in
fashion that changes every year so these

how many should I buy of what Styles put
it in what stores so retailers are
making decisions around these so they

once that inventory is bought the next
focuses on allocations and this is

they're figuring out decision in terms

online
in orders that you pay place and some of

and classes and so on
so by optimization essentially
specifically involves two sorts of
questions which merchants and buyers and
retailers need to answer so for example
here there's a sweater and that's being
offered for the upcoming season as a
merchant I need to decide should I buy
this sweater if I should buy how many of
these sweaters should I buy how should i
split my body budget which has been
allocated to me across this sweater and
other sweaters based on a bunch of
constraints but the constraints come in
not only because of the total budget but
there's also some constraints in terms
of you know you need to maintain certain
breadth of assortments in stores certain
set of sizes different materials and so
on so there's a bunch of business rules
which come into play in the second
question which is figuring out actually
how to split my split the budget so to
be more specific what they have is
essentially a bunch of attributes for
each of the products they're looking to
buy so that is what is retailers often
called a buy sheet and a buy sheet is
essentially a bunch of related products
which are in an excel sheet
traditionally the most retailers do this
work in Excel and there's you can see
there's different columns for each row
is a product and there's different
columns they're defining different
attributes for the product so the first
row is the product name there's you know
different sorts of tees and tops the
second product gives an attribute which
is related to what type of cup is it is
a basic tea or fashion tea and so on the
third one is what style it is the fourth
one is the fit fifth is related to the
fabric and so on so these are the bunch
of attributes that a merchant
and on basis of these attributes the
merchant needs to make decision in terms
of what will be the demand of this
product across the country how should I
split my budget across these different
products and so on so that's essentially
the buy optimization problem so now
let's look at what data is available to

typically would use very high-level

some intuition which they're very good
at what we've tried to do is essentially

intuitively we will feel useful
so there's transactions transactions are

essentially you can translate these into

second is the products itself
there's attributes hierarchy images and

so I won't go through the precise

10-minute talk but I do want to give you

there's assortment variation across

this assortment variation across time

we take the transactions which is the
historical demand and then figure out a
function which essentially Maps the
attributes and the time to the demand
for that product so that gives the raw
demand for the product and we use the
mix of techniques so there's random
forests which creates a decision tree on
the attributes there's a bunch of
regressions we run after embedding text
and images into a vector space to figure
out how that maps into the sales and
then there's a time series production
component where we are actually
projecting demand into the future for
the entire crop of products so that's
that's the machine learning pipeline but
what we did is we kept the interface the
same for the merchants because the
merchants are still working with the buy

so what they do is they upload the my

then we use the attributes of the new

essentially understand to help the
buyers
optimize how they should invest across
different products so one challenge that
we ran into even though our predictions

we ran into is adoption and this is I

humans interacting with machine learning

provide a provenance
so provenance is in this context so if

a high
red and blue this is a bi shield with a

thing we did has provided merchants some

versus what they get from the production

are traditionally retail has mostly
worked using siloed data merchants use
different data EECOM parents are
different date and so on so bringing all
